questions.question: The most effective audit procedure to test the existence assertion for property, plant, and equipment is:

options.A: Examining invoices and purchase documents
options.B: Physical inspection of selected assets
options.C: Reviewing depreciation calculations
options.D: Confirming balances with management

questions.explanation: Physical inspection provides direct evidence that assets recorded in the accounting records actually exist. While documentation testing supports other assertions, seeing the asset confirms its existence.
questions.tip: Existence = see it. Physical inspection is the gold standard for fixed assets.

questions.question: To test that recorded asset additions are properly supported, an auditor would:

options.A: Trace from the asset register to purchase invoices
options.B: Trace from purchase orders to the asset register
options.C: Confirm additions with the vendor
options.D: Review board minutes for all additions

questions.explanation: Vouching from the asset register to supporting documentation (invoices, contracts) tests that recorded additions actually occurred and are properly supported. This tests the occurrence/existence and valuation assertions.
questions.tip: Vouching = records → support. Tests occurrence and proper recording.

questions.question: When testing depreciation expense, the auditor should verify that:

options.A: Assets are depreciated using the same method as competitors
options.B: The method, useful life, and salvage value are reasonable and consistently applied
options.C: Depreciation expense equals one-twelfth of original cost per month
options.D: All assets are fully depreciated within five years

questions.explanation: The auditor tests that depreciation methods, useful lives, and salvage values are reasonable for the nature of the assets and are consistently applied. Changes should be accounted for appropriately.
questions.tip: Depreciation = method + useful life + salvage value. All must be reasonable and consistent.

questions.question: To test the completeness assertion for fixed assets, an auditor would most likely:

options.A: Select items from the asset register and locate the physical asset
options.B: Select items during physical inspection and trace to the asset register
options.C: Confirm asset balances with insurance companies
options.D: Review depreciation expense for reasonableness

questions.explanation: Completeness testing traces from the source (physical assets) to the records (asset register). Selecting assets observed during inspection and tracing to records tests whether all existing assets are recorded.
questions.tip: Completeness = physical → records. Ensure everything that exists is recorded.

questions.question: An auditor suspects improper capitalization of expenses. Which procedure would best address this concern?

options.A: Reviewing repairs and maintenance expense for items that should be capitalized
options.B: Confirming asset balances with vendors
options.C: Testing depreciation calculations
options.D: Reviewing the asset register for fully depreciated items

questions.explanation: Improper capitalization can go either direction. Reviewing repairs and maintenance for items exceeding the capitalization threshold or extending asset life helps identify costs that should have been capitalized.
questions.tip: Review expense accounts for items that should be capitalized—test the policy threshold.

questions.question: When testing fixed asset disposals, the auditor should verify that:

options.A: Gains on disposal were maximized
options.B: The asset, accumulated depreciation, and any gain or loss were properly recorded
options.C: Disposals were approved by shareholders
options.D: Replaced assets had identical useful lives

questions.explanation: Disposal testing verifies that the asset cost and related accumulated depreciation were removed, proceeds were properly recorded, and any gain or loss was correctly calculated and classified.
questions.tip: Disposal = remove cost + remove accumulated depreciation + record proceeds + recognize gain/loss.

questions.question: When evaluating whether assets are impaired, the auditor should:

options.A: Require an independent appraisal for all fixed assets
options.B: Assess whether triggering events exist and evaluate management's impairment analysis
options.C: Test whether market value exceeds book value for each asset
options.D: Rely on management's assertion that no impairment exists

questions.explanation: The auditor evaluates whether indicators of impairment exist (triggering events) and, if so, assesses the reasonableness of management's impairment testing methodology and conclusions, including cash flow projections.
questions.tip: Impairment: First identify triggers, then evaluate management's analysis if triggers exist.

questions.question: When auditing construction in progress, the auditor should be particularly concerned that:

options.A: The contractor is financially stable
options.B: Costs are properly accumulated and assets are transferred to service when complete
options.C: Construction is completed on schedule
options.D: All construction contracts were competitively bid

questions.explanation: CIP auditing focuses on proper cost accumulation (including capitalized interest) and timely transfer to depreciable asset categories when the asset is placed in service. Delays in transfer understate depreciation expense.
questions.tip: CIP: Test cost accumulation + timely transfer to service. Watch for late transfers.

questions.question: Under ASC 842, when auditing a client's leases, the auditor should verify that:

options.A: All leases are classified as operating leases
options.B: Right-of-use assets and lease liabilities are properly recognized and measured
options.C: Lease payments equal fair rental value
options.D: Leases with related parties are excluded from the balance sheet

questions.explanation: Under ASC 842, lessees must recognize right-of-use assets and lease liabilities for most leases. The auditor verifies proper identification of leases, classification, measurement of assets and liabilities, and disclosure.
questions.tip: ASC 842 = almost all leases on balance sheet. Test ROU asset and liability measurement.

questions.question: Which analytical procedure would most effectively identify potential misstatements in fixed assets?

options.A: Comparing the current ratio to prior year
options.B: Calculating depreciation as a percentage of gross fixed assets and comparing to prior periods
options.C: Comparing sales growth to industry averages
options.D: Analyzing the accounts payable aging

questions.explanation: Depreciation as a percentage of gross assets should be relatively stable if depreciation methods and asset mix remain consistent. Unusual changes may indicate errors in depreciation calculations or asset additions/disposals.
questions.tip: Depreciation/Assets ratio should be stable. Changes warrant investigation.

questions.question: To verify the client has rights to fixed assets, the auditor should:

options.A: Confirm the asset's location
options.B: Review titles, deeds, or lease agreements
options.C: Test depreciation calculations
options.D: Observe the asset during the physical count

questions.explanation: Rights and obligations are tested by examining evidence of ownership such as titles, deeds, vehicle registrations, or lease documents that demonstrate the client has legal rights to the recorded assets.
questions.tip: Rights = legal documentation proving ownership (titles, deeds, leases).

questions.question: If fixed assets are pledged as collateral for a loan, the auditor should ensure:

options.A: The assets are removed from the balance sheet
options.B: Appropriate disclosure is made in the financial statements
options.C: The loan is paid off before year-end
options.D: The assets are revalued to loan value

questions.explanation: Assets pledged as collateral remain on the balance sheet but require disclosure of the pledge. Users need to understand that these assets may not be available to satisfy other creditors if the company defaults.
questions.tip: Pledged assets = stay on balance sheet but require disclosure of the encumbrance.

questions.question: Fully depreciated assets still in use should be:

options.A: Removed from the accounting records immediately
options.B: Retained in the records until disposed of
options.C: Revalued to current market value
options.D: Transferred to a separate contra account

questions.explanation: Fully depreciated assets still in service should remain in the accounting records at cost less accumulated depreciation (net book value of zero) until retired or disposed of. This maintains accurate records for insurance and tax purposes.
questions.tip: Fully depreciated ≠ remove from books. Keep until physical disposal.

questions.question: An effective internal control over fixed assets is:

options.A: Depreciating all assets over the same useful life
options.B: Assigning unique identification tags to each asset
options.C: Requiring board approval for all asset purchases
options.D: Using the same vendor for all asset purchases

questions.explanation: Unique identification tags allow assets to be tracked throughout their life, facilitate physical inventories, and help prevent theft or unauthorized movement. Tags link physical assets to accounting records.
questions.tip: Asset tags = control and tracking mechanism. Enables physical-to-records reconciliation.

questions.question: When auditing capitalized interest on a self-constructed asset, the auditor should verify:

options.A: All interest expense during the year was capitalized
options.B: Interest was capitalized only during the construction period based on qualifying expenditures
options.C: Interest was capitalized at the company's highest borrowing rate
options.D: Capitalized interest does not exceed total construction costs

questions.explanation: Interest capitalization is limited to the construction period and based on qualifying expenditures. The auditor tests that interest capitalization began when construction started and ceased when the asset was substantially complete.
questions.tip: Capitalized interest: Only during construction, only on qualifying expenditures.

questions.question: When using an external appraiser to value fixed assets, the auditor should:

options.A: Accept the appraiser's value without further testing
options.B: Evaluate the appraiser's competence, objectivity, and methodology
options.C: Require the appraiser to be approved by the SEC
options.D: Use only appraisers employed by the client

questions.explanation: The auditor must evaluate the specialist's competence and objectivity, understand the methodology used, and assess whether the appraiser's findings are appropriate audit evidence for the assertion being tested.
questions.tip: Specialist work requires auditor evaluation of competence, objectivity, and methodology.

questions.question: When auditing an asset retirement obligation (ARO), the auditor should evaluate:

options.A: Whether management has a legal obligation to retire the asset
options.B: The reasonableness of estimated costs and discount rate used
options.C: Whether the ARO exceeds 10% of total liabilities
options.D: The expected date of retirement only

questions.explanation: ARO auditing requires evaluating whether a legal obligation exists, the reasonableness of estimated retirement costs, the appropriateness of the discount rate, and subsequent accretion expense calculations.
questions.tip: ARO = legal obligation + reasonable cost estimate + appropriate discount rate + accretion.

questions.question: When should an asset be depreciated using component depreciation?

options.A: Only when required by industry regulations
options.B: When major components have significantly different useful lives
options.C: When the asset exceeds the capitalization threshold
options.D: Only for government-funded assets

questions.explanation: Component depreciation is appropriate when major parts of an asset have significantly different useful lives. Each component is depreciated separately over its useful life, providing more accurate matching of expense.
questions.tip: Component depreciation = when parts have materially different lives (building vs roof).

questions.question: A periodic physical inventory of fixed assets helps ensure:

options.A: Depreciation is calculated correctly
options.B: Recorded assets exist and unrecorded assets are identified
options.C: Asset values are updated to market
options.D: Insurance coverage is adequate

questions.explanation: Physical inventory of fixed assets verifies that recorded assets exist and are in use, and may identify unrecorded assets or assets that should have been removed from the books. This is an important control activity.
questions.tip: Physical inventory of fixed assets = existence and completeness testing by the client.

questions.question: A change in the estimated useful life of an asset is accounted for:

options.A: Retrospectively with restatement of prior years
options.B: Prospectively over the remaining useful life
options.C: As a prior period adjustment
options.D: By immediately writing off the remaining book value

questions.explanation: Changes in accounting estimates, including useful lives, are accounted for prospectively. The remaining book value is depreciated over the revised remaining useful life going forward.
questions.tip: Change in estimate = prospective. No restatement, adjust depreciation going forward.

questions.question: The cost of a purchased fixed asset includes:

options.A: Purchase price only
options.B: Purchase price plus all costs necessary to bring the asset to its intended use
options.C: Purchase price less any trade discount
options.D: Fair market value at date of purchase

questions.explanation: Asset cost includes the purchase price and all costs necessary to prepare the asset for its intended use, such as freight, installation, testing, and site preparation. Trade discounts reduce the recorded cost.
questions.tip: Asset cost = all costs to get it ready for intended use, not just purchase price.

questions.question: When auditing an exchange of nonmonetary assets with commercial substance, the auditor should verify that:

options.A: No gain or loss was recognized
options.B: The asset received is recorded at fair value and any gain or loss is recognized
options.C: The asset received is recorded at the book value of the asset given up
options.D: Both assets were appraised by the same specialist

questions.explanation: Exchanges with commercial substance (cash flows change) are recorded at fair value of assets given up or received, with gain or loss recognized. The auditor verifies fair value determination and proper gain/loss calculation.
questions.tip: Commercial substance = use fair value, recognize gain/loss. No substance = carry over basis.

questions.question: When an asset is temporarily idle, the auditor should verify that:

options.A: Depreciation has been suspended during the idle period
options.B: Depreciation continues and impairment is considered
options.C: The asset is removed from the balance sheet
options.D: The asset is reclassified as inventory

questions.explanation: Temporarily idle assets continue to be depreciated as the asset is still wearing out or becoming obsolete. Additionally, idle status may be an indicator of impairment requiring evaluation.
questions.tip: Idle assets: depreciation continues + consider impairment indicators.

questions.question: Under IFRS, if a company uses the revaluation model for a class of PPE, the auditor should verify:

options.A: Revaluations are performed consistently for the entire class
options.B: Only increases in value are recorded
options.C: Revaluations are optional and can be selective
options.D: Revaluation is required annually for all assets

questions.explanation: Under IFRS, if the revaluation model is elected, it must be applied consistently to an entire class of assets. Revaluations must be kept sufficiently current, and increases go to OCI while decreases typically go to expense.
questions.tip: IFRS revaluation = whole class consistently, not cherry-picking assets.

questions.question: Required disclosures for property, plant, and equipment include:

options.A: Names of vendors supplying the assets
options.B: Depreciation methods and useful lives by major asset class
options.C: Original purchase date for each asset
options.D: Insurance coverage amounts

questions.explanation: PPE disclosures must include depreciation methods and useful lives used, gross carrying amounts, accumulated depreciation, and information about pledged assets or significant commitments for construction.
questions.tip: PPE disclosures = methods, useful lives, gross amounts, accumulated depreciation, pledges.

questions.question: An expenditure that extends an asset's useful life beyond original estimates should be:

options.A: Expensed immediately
options.B: Capitalized as a betterment
options.C: Recorded as prepaid expense
options.D: Charged to accumulated depreciation

questions.explanation: Betterments that extend useful life or improve efficiency should be capitalized. The auditor tests whether the client properly distinguishes between routine maintenance (expense) and capital improvements (capitalize).
questions.tip: Extends life or improves function = capitalize. Maintains existing condition = expense.

questions.question: When auditing land, the auditor should note that:

options.A: Land should be depreciated over 40 years
options.B: Land is not depreciated but land improvements are
options.C: Land and buildings should always be combined
options.D: Land should be revalued annually to market

questions.explanation: Land has an indefinite useful life and is not depreciated. However, land improvements (parking lots, landscaping, etc.) have finite lives and are depreciated separately from the land.
questions.tip: Land = no depreciation. Land improvements = depreciate separately.

questions.question: When a fixed asset is acquired with government grant funds, the auditor should verify:

options.A: The asset is recorded at zero cost
options.B: Proper accounting treatment and compliance with grant terms including potential recapture provisions
options.C: The grant funds are recorded as revenue immediately
options.D: No depreciation is recorded on the asset

questions.explanation: Assets acquired with grants require proper accounting (asset at cost with deferred revenue or net method) and compliance with grant terms. Many grants have recapture provisions if the asset is sold or misused.
questions.tip: Grant-funded assets: proper accounting + comply with grant terms + watch recapture provisions.

questions.question: After year-end, a major asset is destroyed by fire. This subsequent event requires:

options.A: Adjustment of year-end financial statements to remove the asset
options.B: Disclosure if the loss is material and conditions arose after year-end
options.C: No action since it occurred after year-end
options.D: Restatement of all prior period financial statements

questions.explanation: A post year-end casualty loss is a Type II subsequent event (conditions arose after year-end). If material, it requires disclosure but not adjustment of year-end financial statements unless the asset was already impaired.
questions.tip: Post year-end destruction = disclosure only (Type II) unless impairment existed at year-end.

questions.question: When auditing assets owned through a joint venture, the auditor should:

options.A: Exclude such assets from the audit
options.B: Verify the client's proportionate share is properly reflected per the accounting method used
options.C: Require consolidation of all joint venture assets
options.D: Confirm ownership only with the joint venture partner

questions.explanation: The auditor verifies that joint venture assets are accounted for appropriately under the applicable method (equity method or proportionate consolidation if permitted). The client's share should be properly reflected in the financial statements.
questions.tip: Joint venture assets: verify proper method and proportionate share is correctly recorded.

questions.question: For internally developed software, costs should be capitalized starting when:

options.A: The project is approved by management
options.B: Technological feasibility has been established
options.C: The software is placed in service
options.D: All development costs have been incurred

questions.explanation: For software developed for sale, costs are capitalized after technological feasibility is established. For internal-use software, capitalization begins during the application development stage after the preliminary project stage.
questions.tip: Software capitalization starts at technological feasibility (sale) or application development stage (internal).

questions.question: Because fixed assets typically have few transactions, auditors commonly use a rollforward approach that:

options.A: Tests ending balances only without reference to beginning balances
options.B: Reconciles beginning balances, tests additions and disposals, and proves to ending balances
options.C: Relies entirely on analytical procedures
options.D: Tests only the largest five assets each year

questions.explanation: The rollforward approach starts with verified beginning balances, tests current year additions and disposals, and reconciles to ending balances. This is efficient because fixed asset populations change relatively little year to year.
questions.tip: PPE rollforward: Beginning balance + additions - disposals = ending balance. Test the changes.

questions.question: Reviewing board minutes can provide evidence about fixed assets by revealing:

options.A: Depreciation calculations
options.B: Authorized acquisitions, disposals, or pledges of significant assets
options.C: Physical location of assets
options.D: Vendor payment terms

questions.explanation: Board minutes may reveal authorization of major capital expenditures, significant asset disposals, or decisions to pledge assets as collateral. This helps identify transactions requiring audit attention and test authorization.
questions.tip: Board minutes = authorization evidence + identify significant transactions for testing.

questions.conceptTested: Classification of held for sale assets
questions.question: An asset classified as held for sale should be:

options.A: Continued to be depreciated normally
options.B: Measured at lower of carrying amount or fair value less costs to sell
options.C: Removed from the balance sheet immediately
options.D: Revalued to current market value

questions.explanation: Assets held for sale are measured at the lower of carrying amount or fair value less costs to sell. Depreciation ceases once classified as held for sale. The auditor tests whether classification criteria are met.
questions.tip: Held for sale: stop depreciation + measure at lower of book or FV less selling costs.

questions.question: Assets received as donations should be recorded at:

options.A: Zero since no cost was incurred
options.B: Fair value at the date of donation
options.C: The donor's book value
options.D: Appraised value when sold

questions.explanation: Donated assets are recorded at fair value at the date of donation, with a corresponding credit to contribution revenue (or contra expense for governmental). The auditor verifies fair value determination and proper recording.
questions.tip: Donated assets = fair value at donation date. Must determine FV even though no cash exchanged.
